TRAVEL ISSUE OF BLUE
JAY TO APPEAR ON 14th
The next issue of the Black
and Blue Jay will make its appearance at the Barnstormer
Play, and will be placed in post
office boxes a day or two before the play. Copies will be
sold at the Lyric. As previously announced, the issue'vvill
be both a Travel Number and
a Barnstormer Number, as
copy pertaining to both theatrical subjects and travel experiences will be included.

OLD GOLD CIGARETTE TROUPE
GIVES TEST AT UNIVERSITY

LINTHICUM IS ELECTED
AS COUNCIL DELEGATE
Sweetster Linthicum was
elected as one of the Junior
representatives to the Student
Council at the elections held
last Thursday. Lyons and
Scheidt were the other, candidates for the position.
Linthicum's election fills the
vacancy made by Markle, when
the latter left the University
several months ago. Polls were
open for the election from
12:30 to 1.

thesame night and at the same hour, the Interfraternity Ball was beinc held at the Maiyland Casualty Clubhouse. Few students were
willing to attend the are, unmaculately•attired in evening dress.
Fewer still wished to risk then partners: dancing frocks on the Carlin's circus mita Consequently, only a: small number of undergraduates were on band to witness one of the most exciting cage corve.s
of the season.
Two weeks ago, a similar catastrophe occurred because of sameone's negligence. Both the Musical Club and the alumni decided to
hold their annual entertainments on the same evening. While the
graduates were puffing cigars and listening to speeches at the Alumni
Memorial Hall, the undergraduate musicians were performing at the
Cedar Avenue auditorium.
The University Calendar is a certain guarantee against such damming conflicts. More care should be exercised in its use

CITY COLLEGE DEFEATS
FRESHMEN SWIMMERS
Winning only„te out.of the seven events, and those two by mere
one-point marginS, the Hopkins
Freshmen dropped their swimming
,
meet Friday to the Baltimore City
College team. The score was 433/2
to 16%.
Donovan and Dorman won first
places for Hopkins, and thereby the
slender leads in those events. They
Were fancy diving and the 100-yard
breast stroke, respectively. In each
case City captured both other scoring places—in fact, they couldn't
avoid it. since the only other two
men entered in those events were
from City College.
City opened by taking the lead in
the 200 yard relay, 6-0. In the.second and third events the freshmen
Ja)..• tasted their only wins, and
theili dropped back for the rest of
the meet while the prep schools
consistently- widened the gulf separating. the ,scores, finishing by a
succession of three first and second
places.
The whole meet was rather listless and the very meagre gathering
was composed entirely of small boys
from City College. The participants
in the fancy diving contest weye accorded a mechanical applause, despite the request of John Norris,
Hopkins' varsity manager, that it be
omitted.'

Scabbard and Blade
Holds Annual Dance
Last Saturday night, the Hopkins
Unit of Scabbard and Blade gave its
annual dance. Probably, due to the
Interfraternity BaIlL having.. been
held on the previous night, the military function was poorly attended,
only about a half hundred couples
being present.
Decorations were unusual, and
made the C. E. Hall look like an
armory. On platforms at both ends
of the hall, the military department
had placed machine guns, trench
mortars, and ten-pounders, and interspersed among these weapons
were rifles stacked around regimental colors. On the corners of the
platforms there were additional
groupings of bunting, while American flags placed at intervals lent
color to the general scheme. As advertised, Bob Iula was there in person.
Major and Mrs. McKinney and
Capt. and Mrs. Bass were the chaperones. Most of those in attendance
were.members of the local R. 0. T.
C. 'Unit, but although it was requested, not all members of the local
unit were in attendance. The dance,
which,started at nine, ended at midnight, with the playing of the StarSpangled Banner.

again lost to the St. John's Juniors

for the yearlings to reach and they
held their lead by superior passwork.

to be the best man on the floor,
while Kneip performed brilliantly
for'Hopkins.

CITY COLLEGE DEFEATS
FRESHMEN SWIMMERS
Winning only„te out.of the seven events, and those two by mere
one-point marginS, the Hopkins
Freshmen dropped their swimming
,
meet Friday to the Baltimore City
College team. The score was 433/2
to 16%.
Donovan and Dorman won first
places for Hopkins, and thereby the
slender leads in those events. They
Were fancy diving and the 100-yard
breast stroke, respectively. In each
case City captured both other scoring places—in fact, they couldn't
avoid it. since the only other two
men entered in those events were
from City College.
City opened by taking the lead in
the 200 yard relay, 6-0. In the.second and third events the freshmen
Ja)..• tasted their only wins, and
theili dropped back for the rest of
the meet while the prep schools
consistently- widened the gulf separating. the ,scores, finishing by a
succession of three first and second
places.
The whole meet was rather listless and the very meagre gathering
was composed entirely of small boys
from City College. The participants
in the fancy diving contest weye accorded a mechanical applause, despite the request of John Norris,
Hopkins' varsity manager, that it be
omitted.'

Scabbard and Blade
Holds Annual Dance
Last Saturday night, the Hopkins
Unit of Scabbard and Blade gave its
annual dance. Probably, due to the
Interfraternity BaIlL having.. been
held on the previous night, the military function was poorly attended,
only about a half hundred couples
being present.
Decorations were unusual, and
made the C. E. Hall look like an
armory. On platforms at both ends
of the hall, the military department
had placed machine guns, trench
mortars, and ten-pounders, and interspersed among these weapons
were rifles stacked around regimental colors. On the corners of the
platforms there were additional
groupings of bunting, while American flags placed at intervals lent
color to the general scheme. As advertised, Bob Iula was there in person.
Major and Mrs. McKinney and
Capt. and Mrs. Bass were the chaperones. Most of those in attendance
were.members of the local R. 0. T.
C. 'Unit, but although it was requested, not all members of the local
unit were in attendance. The dance,
which,started at nine, ended at midnight, with the playing of the StarSpangled Banner.

. The Freshman basketball team
again lost to the St. John's Juniors

much interest and ended with the
score at five to four in favor of the
"Johnnie's"

exciting, and the St.,Johns men ran
-up a score which was a bit too much
for the yearlings to reach and they
held their lead by superior passwork.
Ward was the leading point scorer
for the visitors and proved himself
to be the best man on the floor,
while Kneip performed brilliantly
for'Hopkins.
